Half-Life 2 builds even more on the mechanics that made the original such a great game. The setting, a dystopian world ravaged by the apocalyptic events of the first game, immerses the player in what appears to be a droll and depressing society controlled by a dictator of sorts. Being put back into the world of Half-Life it leaves you with a lot of questions as to how and why things happened the way they did, and it is up to the player to create their own explanations for the most part. The variety of weapons and enemies that you encounter all keep the game fresh as you progress through the story. The brilliance of Valve shines through multiple times throughout this campaign, as they build on gameplay mechanics that made the first one a classic. In the first Half-Life, you are for the most part on your own escaping a nuclear meltdown that caused interdimensional aliens to invade the Earth. That game was a solitary story of survival. This one is a tale of a savior, alongside his fellow oppressed citizens, toppling an authoritarian regime focused on selling out the human population. In my opnion, it still holds up even 14 years later.

Not really a fan of first person shooters, but this one was pretty fun. I didn't like some parts of it, but most of those were ambushes and other things that the player shouldn't be expected to know on their first time through. I hated it at first, but I guess this is supposed to be a game based on trial and error. There was one part that seemed to just be pure luck, though.

*Spoilers, sort of*
There is a part in chapter 11 where a Stryder has to blow up a wall to allow the player to pass. When I played, it seemed arbitrary whether or not it would actually blow up the wall when it passed by.  I didn't find anything except "wait for the Stryder to blow up the wall" on any guides, and so I waited. The infinitely spawning enemies didn't help me survive longer than five minutes, but there were some handy corners which allowed me to not be hit. When the Stryder finally DID blow up the wall, I had pretty much just restarted, so I think this may just be the fault of the good ol' RNG. In the end, getting the Stryder to let me progress took about as long as all of chapter 12.

Over all, fun, but not too good.
